holidays.name: Winnie the Pooh Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the lovable bear created by A.A. Milne on the birthday of his creator. It’s a day to dive into the Hundred Acre Wood with Pooh, Tigger, Piglet, and friends!
holidays.origin: Honors the birthday of author A.A. Milne, born January 18, 1882, who penned the famous Winnie the Pooh stories.
holidays.funFact: Winnie the Pooh was inspired by a real bear named Winnie at the London Zoo, visited by Milne’s son Christopher Robin, who inspired the fictional character.

holidays.name: Thesaurus Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the thesaurus — the wonderful tool that helps you find synonyms and spice up your vocabulary! Perfect for writers, students, and word lovers.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the first publication of Peter Mark Roget’s Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases in 1852.
holidays.funFact: The thesaurus was not invented to help writers sound fancy, but originally as a tool to help organize knowledge in a logical order.

holidays.name: National Winnie the Pooh Day (yes, double Pooh!)
holidays.description: Some calendars list this day twice to emphasize the enduring charm and popularity of Winnie the Pooh in culture, media, and our hearts.
holidays.origin: Based on the same origins as Winnie the Pooh Day, but sometimes officially recognized twice for extra love.
holidays.funFact: The philosophical musings of Pooh have inspired everything from children’s bedtime stories to academic papers on childhood and friendship.

holidays.name: Pioneer Day (Utah)
holidays.description: Commemorating the arrival of Mormon pioneers into the Salt Lake Valley in 1847. It features parades, fireworks, and historic reenactments.
holidays.origin: Marks the day Brigham Young and the first group of Mormon pioneers entered the Salt Lake Valley.
holidays.funFact: While officially a Utah state holiday celebrated on July 24, some pioneer groups commemorate the journey stages on January 18.
